p.s: DelaneysDelaney's development from standing up for his believesbeliefs (l. 2) to a prejudice guided being is is indicated by the reported thought: the man was Mexican (l. 17).
His shock is expressed is expressed through this short sentence and the reader immediately knows that this situation reminds him of his own incident.
The fact that he is struck with the force of a blow (l. 17) by this fact is also indicating that he ahs a problem with Mexicans.

The sudden usage of inner monologue, where Delaney asks himself if this guy is the same man who threatened Kyra (ll. 24-26) shows the growing panic inside of Delaney and that he will probably listen to his prejudical thoughts than to his rational thoughts.
Another passage that describes his irrational behaviour is line 34-36.
In this inner monologue he is jumping to conclusions.
Even after the chat with the man, Delaney wants to call the police (l. 51).
The climax of his prejudical thinking is when he calls the man in a reported thought a liar, thief etc. (ll. 49f).
This sentence also has a climatic structure because his cursing gets worse and worse and ends with a Mexican (l. 50).
It shows that there is no point of turning back for Delaney.
he is controlled by racist thoughts.
He is not only controlled by his prejudice but also by fear.
His fear is expressed by a climatic sentence where he desperately searches for someone who could support him in this situation (ll. 5f).
Delaney is also ready to fight with the Mexican because he expects that the guy has weapons (l. 56).
This is also the climax in this excerpt.
It creates tension and makes the reader curious without telling them the readers question if Delaney's thoughts are right.
Delaney realises that he was guided by fear and prejudice at the end of the chapter (ll. 60f).
He wonders what he is becoming (l. 61) or turning into.
It underlines his self-awareness but also his changing character.
He is not the self assuredself-assured naturalist who tries to act democratically anymore, he now knows how it is when fear and prejudice take over.
